text:
poll time!

when building OpenBLAS v0.3.12+ we hit a GCC bug: <https://gcc.gnu.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=87467>.  this was fixed in GCC 9 (<https://github.com/gcc-mirror/gcc/commit/23bce99cbe7016a04e14c2163ed3fe6a5a64f4e2#diff-c3bbd1dcd7c953ef6d719969fb187e31209ef3d7851a84448aad949aea2e8106>).  <@U679T6QF7> is trying to build OpenBLAS 0.3.13 (<https://github.com/JuliaPackaging/Yggdrasil/pull/2385>), what do you prefer:

1. require GCC v9 :rabbit2:
2. keep the same GCC version, but patch the header file on-the-fly :eagle:

elements.text:

when building OpenBLAS v0.3.12+ we hit a GCC bug:

), what do you prefer:

1. require GCC v9
2. keep the same GCC version, but patch the header file on-the-fly

text: what's the consequences of upgrading to gcc 9?

elements.text: what's the consequences of upgrading to gcc 9?

text: I imagine the downside to (2) is the maintenance overhead

elements.text: I imagine the downside to (2) is the maintenance overhead

text: libraries built with newer GCC versions tend to be incompatible with older systems.  for pure C libraries this isn't usually a big problem in practice, but you never know.  for this reason we tend to use the oldest version of GCC possible

elements.text: libraries built with newer GCC versions tend to be incompatible with older systems.  for pure C libraries this isn't usually a big problem in practice, but you never know.  for this reason we tend to use the oldest version of GCC possible

text: the long-term solution is to install the patch in all of our GCC shards (probably only x86* ones), but it'll take time

elements.text: the long-term solution is to install the patch in all of our GCC shards (probably only x86* ones), but it'll take time
